content: I really enjoyed this one.  The search space is limited enough that I didn't have to use anything fancy, or even backtrace. I could see a harder version forcing us to use a version of your novel solution.  I'm not sure if you change the order in which you check neighbors matters in your solution.  Does it?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting challenge to run a BFS on a hex grid

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nicely done.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: the author seems to be really dedicated to his work and made a lot of efforts to explain clearly the goal of his puzzle. Nice work

Looks good.

You did not precise in the statement if there is only one shortest path so I tested it and there is indeed only one. Maybe it's worth mentionning it.

Also i miss some interesting test case like these :
// blocked ?
4 5
####
#S##
##_#
#E##
####

// blocked v2 ?
4 5
####
##S#
#_##
##E#
####

// corner ?
4 4
####
##S#
#E#_
_##_

// corner v2 ?
4 4
####
#S##
_#E#
_##_

Thank you.

I've just mentionned the only one shortest path.

The corner is tested by the "Everything" test and validator : [bottom left => top left => top right] in test, and [bottom right => top left] in validator. Do you think i really have to do specific tests ?

I can't add the blocked test because there is always a solution, but the first test and validator check the possible diagonals.

No, the order doesn't matter. It'd matter if there were several shortest pathes, but it was not wanted.
How do you suggest to do an harder version ? The contribution is now approved but i want to do other mazes based on hexagonal grid or cells.

That's just a suggestion !
I personnaly like when there is some very simple test case to debug easily (yes unfortunately i always need to debug :p)
The suggestion was :

blocked ? => in fact no even if visually yes
blocked v2 ? => yes but my bad it's not in the statement

corner ? => yes
corner v2 ? => no and output == input !

Ok, i'll add a corner test case in order to debug easily.
For corner v2 it is not a corner problem, i'll add test case with Start near End (not necessary on a corner).
I've updated the statement to say there is always a solution.
